Award.AwardTitle: Crowdsourcing for Engineering Systems Design: Theoretical and Experimental Studies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to establish how the design of a crowdsourcing tournament affects its outcomes in engineering systems design. The objective will be achieved by extending game-theoretic models from contest theory, and performing lab experiments based on behavioral game theory. The research activities include a) analyzing the effects of different tournament design options on the outcomes for individuals, pre-defined teams, and self-organized teams, b) comparing the predictions from analytical game theoretic models with observed contestant behaviors within experimental settings. The overall expected outcome include a theoretical framework and lab experiments to facilitate tournament design. Specific outcomes include non-cooperative games of crowdsourcing tournaments considering unique aspects of engineering systems design, and lab experiments to identify the limits of theoretical models and to guide further theoretical developments.

The results of this research hold promise to enable systems engineers and managers to systematically design crowdsourcing tournaments, a new and growing venue for product design, by considering different tournament design options and their potential impacts on the outcomes. The proposed research will advance the state of the art in engineering design involving strategic decisions, where only analytical models of games have been used. The outcomes of the research are being integrated into graduate and undergraduate courses. The activities are fostering collaboration among researchers in engineering design and experimental economics, and providing broader exposure to the graduate students. The lab experiments, software tools, and data generated as a part of this project are being disseminated through Purdue University Research Repository (PURR), journal publications and conference presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering design and systems engineering organizations are increasingly using crowdsourcing for design-related  activities  such  as  idea  generation  and  evaluation,  and  solving  difficult  problems. To  effectively  use  crowdsourcing  within  engineering  systems  design,  it  is  important  to  systematically  design  crowdsourcing  initiatives  by  considering  conflicting  goals  such  as  maximizing  participation  and  the  quality  of  outcomes  within  cost  constraints.  The project has resulted in a methodological framework and application-specific insights that can be used by systems engineers and managers for informed design of crowdsourcing tournaments by considering different tournament design options and their potential impacts on the outcomes. The methodological framework consists of theoretical models, behavioral experiments, data-driven analysis, and interviews.

The project advances the state of knowledge in engineering design and systems engineering by establishing ways to integrate theoretical modeling of design competitions with behavioral experimentation. New analytical models of design crowdsourcing scenarios have been established based on game-theory. The analytical models extend the state of the art by capturing the nuances of engineering design, such as the strategies related to the design process, the sequential nature of design decisions, the evolution of strategies, heterogeneity among designers, the diversity of knowledge, and the differences in competitors’ expertise. New behavioral experiments are designed and executed to capture the unique aspects of engineering design problems. The experiments enable evidence collection with a high level of control over variables. The outcomes of the project have resulted in guidance on (i) how to use analytical models to design behavioral experiments for design crowdsourcing, (ii) how to synergistically integrate analytical models with evidence from behavioral experiments, and (iii) how simple experiments can be used to quantitatively model the behaviors of contestants in design crowdsourcing.

In addition to controlled behavioral experiments with student subjects, the study also included an analysis of field data and interviews of industry professionals. The use of field data enables the evaluation of assumptions about participants’ decisions within game-theoretic models. A new network-based approach has been developed using Exponential Random Graph Models (ERGMs) in bipartite settings to represent participation decisions. The approach enables a unique synthesis of advanced network modeling techniques and real crowdsourcing data for behavioral analysis. Interviews with industry professionals help illuminate the challenges faced in adopting crowdsourcing as a mode of innovation.

The results of the project provide guidance on how to design competitions and environments that promote greater innovation within organizations with reduced costs for experimentation. Specific insights are gained about how to design crowdsourcing contests to encourage exploration of the design space to better understand the potential solutions and to generate diverse solutions), how to structure contests to improve design quality, how much information about past contests and competitors should be provided to the contestants, how the complexity of the design task and the reputation of sponsors affect participation, and how the incentives affect contestants’ decisions.

 

Broader impacts:

The project has supported the training and education of three graduate students. The project has provided unique opportunities for the students to learn about research problems and techniques at the interface of Engineering and Behavioral Sciences. The students have learnt the systematic approach towards designing lab experiments. Two of the PhD students supported by this project intend to pursue academic careers. Additionally, over 200 undergraduate students were engaged in the project activities through their participation in behavioral experiments. The results of this project have been incorporated into a graduate-level engineering course to expose students to interdisciplinary research on systems science with an emphasis on decision making. The courses provide opportunities to graduate students to learn the state-of-the-art techniques for decision-making in systems design.

The results of the project have been disseminated through seven journal publications and five peer-reviewed conference papers. The results have been presented to the design community at ASME International Design Engineering and Technical Conferences (IDETC), International Conference on Engineering Design (ICED), and Council of Engineering Systems Universities (CESUN), and Design Cognition and Computing (DCC) conferences.
